{{Infobox musical artist | name = Eddie Mapp | image = | caption = | image_size = | background = non_vocal_instrumentalist | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = c. 1910
[[Social Circle, Georgia]], [[United States]] | death_date = November 14, 1931
[[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], Georgia, United States | instrument = [[Harmonica]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Country blues]] | occupation = [[List of harmonicists|Harmonicist]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1922–1931 | label = Various | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Eddie Mapp''' (c. 1910 – November 14, 1931) was an [[United States|American]] [[country blues]] [[list of harmonicists|harmonicist]]. He is best known for his accompaniment on [[gramophone record|record]] of both [[Barbecue Bob]] and [[Curley Weaver]]. ==Biography== Mapp was born in [[Social Circle, Georgia|Social Circle]], [[Walton County, Georgia|Walton County]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. He relocated in 1922 to [[Newton County, Georgia|Newton County]], where he met the [[guitar]] player, [[Curley Weaver]]. Although he did not sing, Mapp was noted in Newton County as a harmonica virtuoso with a unique style, who often performed for tips on the street. In 1925 Weaver and Mapp left for [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]]. The twosome played at country dances, then Weaver together with [[Barbecue Bob]] and his brother [[Charley Lincoln|Charlie Hicks]] formed a group with Mapp, and continued to play locally.{{cite book | first= Tony | last= Russell | year= 1997 | title= The Blues - From [[Robert Johnson (musician)|Robert Johnson]] to [[Robert Cray]] | edition= | publisher=Carlton Books Limited | location= Dubai | page= 182 | isbn= 1-85868-255-X}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_bh.htm |title=Barbeque Bob HICKS |publisher=Thebluestrail.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} In 1929, and billed as the Georgia Cotton Pickers, they recorded for the Atlanta based QRS [[record label|label]]. Mapp also cut one solo track, "Riding the Blinds", the same year. None of the songs sold well.{{cite web|url=http://www.the-blindman.com/vids/Eddie%20Mapp.htm |title=Eddie Mapp |publisher=The-blindman.com |date=1931-11-14 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/georgia-cotton-pickers |title=Georgia Cotton Pickers: Information from |publisher=Answers.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} In November 1931, Mapp was discovered stabbed on an Atlanta street corner. His death certificate recorded that the [[brachial artery]] in his left arm had been severed, and gave his age as twenty. No one was charged with his murder. The certificate also noted his employment as 'musician', unusual at the time for a [[coroner]] to acknowledge Mapp's status.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p255298/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Eddie Mapp |author=Chadbourne, Eugene |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=January 16, 2010}} - [[Allmusic]] duly notes that there is some doubt regarding Mapp's year of birth. ==Discography== A [[compilation album]], released in 1994, on [[Document Records]] (DOCD-5110), provided the most complete discography of Mapp's work. It was entitled ''Georgia Blues 1928-33''.{{cite web|url=http://www.patmissin.com/ffaq/q5.html |title=Who was the first blues harp player to record? |publisher=Patmissin.com |date=1924-01-31 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} The track listing included the following pieces which featured Mapp's music. Curley Weaver with Eddie Mapp - "No No Blues"; "It's The Best Stuff Yet"; Eddie Mapp and Guy Lumpkin - "Decatur Street Drag"; "Riding The Blinds"; Slim Barton, Eddie Mapp and James Moore - "I'm Hot Like That"; "Careless Love"; "Wicked Travelin' Blues"; "It's Tight Like That"; "Poor Convict Blues"; Eddie Mapp, James Moore and Guy Lumpkin - "Where You Been So Long" (1929);{{cite web|url=http://www.cduniverse.com/search/xx/music/pid/1021189/a/Georgia+Blues+(1928-1933).htm |title=Georgia Blues (1928-1933) CD Album |publisher=Cduniverse.com |date=2000-09-08 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Slim Barton and Eddie Mapp - "Fourth Avenue Blues" (1929){{cite web|url=http://prewarblues.org/category/prewarbluesorg/ |title=Honey, Where You Been So Long? |publisher=Prewarblues.org |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} ==See also== {{portal|Biography|Music|Georgia (U.S. state)}} *[[List of country blues musicians]] *[[List of harmonica blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata | NAME =Mapp, Eddie | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION =[[United States|American]] [[country blues]] harmonicist | DATE OF BIRTH =1910 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Social Circle, Georgia]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH =November 14, 1931 | PLACE OF DEATH =[[Atlanta, Georgia]], United States }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mapp, Eddie}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1931 deaths]] [[Category:1931 crimes]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues harmonica players]] [[Category:Deaths by stabbing in the United States]] [[Category:Harmonica blues musicians]] [[Category:Musicians from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Songwriters from Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:People murdered in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:People from Walton County, Georgia]] [[Category:American murder victims]]
